qas.question: When were the first constitutions for Freemasonry printed?

context: At the dawn of the Grand Lodge era, <a0_0><a5_0><b10_0>during the 1720s<b10_0/><a5_0/><a0_0/>, <a1_0><a6_0><b11_0>James Anderson<b11_0/><a6_0/><a1_0/> composed the first printed constitutions for Freemasons, the basis for most subsequent constitutions, which specifically excluded <a2_0><a7_0><b12_0>women<b12_0/><a7_0/><a2_0/> from Freemasonry. As Freemasonry spread, continental masons began to include their ladies in <a3_0><a8_0><b13_0><b14_0>Lodges of Adoption<b14_0/><b13_0/><a8_0/><a3_0/>, which worked three degrees with the same names as the men's but different content. <a9_0>The French<a9_0/> officially abandoned the experiment in the <a4_0>early 19th century<a4_0/>. Later organisations with a similar aim emerged in the United States, but distinguished the names of the degrees from those of male masonry.
